issue.title: JsonInclude.Include.NON_EMPTY does not replace deprecated WRITE_EMPTY_JSON_ARRAYS

repository.name: jackson-annotations
repository.description: Core annotations (annotations that only depend on jackson-core) for Jackson data processor

body:
Glad to see the need for this functionality need is taken seriously.
What kind of config it ends up as does not matter to me, but here are a couple of thoughts for now:

- The Javadoc should be changed straight away so as not to send more people on a wild-goose-chase for the nonexistent config override
- There are two distinct use cases with important differences:
  - Providing a default config when POJOs are not annotated. This is covered pretty well.
  - Overriding annotations globally.  It would be really great to have a _general_ mechanism for this. Sometimes you don't control the POJOs, and sometimes you just need different behaviour in different contexts. The annotations are great, but they can only say one thing. Conversely you can easily have many different serialisers for varying requierments. Also, the POJOs are sometimes much more 'distant' from you feature code than your (de)serializer.  It is not always pertinent to modify your core model to support a localised I/O need.

Some quick notes: there is a way to define global defaults for some annotatable things already using "config overrides" (added in 2.9), so that in case of inclusion (as an example):

1. There is a global base setting (`ObjectMapper.setDefaultPropertyInclusion()`)
2. There is per-type (class) override (`ObjectMapper.configOverride(MyType.class).setIncludeAsProperty()`)
3. Per-property annotation can further change setting

and I hope to extend coverage for more things; for now, `@JsonInclude`, `@JsonFormat` and couple of others are covered.

But as importantly, for 3.0 I hope to add step between 1 and 2 for "class categories" like "all scalars", "all collections" -- we'll see how that goes. This would in some form allow "all types that map to JSON Array" (or a small set of things you could use, things get hairy between JSON/Java mapping).

Documentation is a good point but... it is obviously quite tricky, if there is no clear replacement.
Obviously we are open to incremental improvements.

Not sure if above helps, but thought it worth sharing.

issue.title: Upgrade to latest version of Jackson (2.10.0). Better fix for #1714

repository.name: fabric8-maven-plugin
repository.description: ðŸ“¢ This project is migrated to ðŸ‘‰  https://github.com/eclipse/jkube

issue.body:
https://github.com/fabric8io/fabric8-maven-plugin/pull/1716 made the generated YAML files a lot less readable, but fixed #1714. I did some investigation, and it seems like our issue is caused by a bug in Jackson. The bug was still present in version 2.9.10, but fixed in 2.10.0.

This PR contains the following:
1. Revert the temporary fix for #1714 prepared by @rohanKanojia.
1. Introduce Jackson BOM to get dependency management on Jackson dependencies
1. Upgrade Jackson to the latest release (2.10.0)
1. Add dependency management for snakeyaml. Jackson requires a newer version than the default managed version by Maven (because of docker-maven-plugin).

There are several ways to fix the last issue/change. Please advice if you want me to do something else. I.e. exclude the transitive dependency pulled in by the dependency to docker-maven-plugin.
